In Sokolów Malopolski during the 18th and 19th centuries, the Jewish community was divided between those who followed the Hasidic movement and those who adhered to more traditional Jewish practices. The Hasidic movement, which emerged in Eastern Europe in the 18th century, emphasized the importance of ecstatic prayer, personal devotion, and the guidance of a charismatic leader known as a rebbe.

The followers of the Hasidic movement in Sokolów Malopolski were known as Hasidim, and they were attracted to the town by the presence of several prominent Hasidic rabbis and leaders. These rabbis, such as Rabbi Menachem Mendel Hager and Rabbi Yitzhak Meir, were known for their charismatic leadership and their ability to connect with their followers on a personal level. Hasidic Jews in Sokolów Malopolski emphasized the importance of joy, song, and dance in their worship, and they sought to cultivate a close relationship with their rebbe as a spiritual guide and mentor.

The more traditional Jews in Sokolów Malopolski, on the other hand, adhered to a more conventional form of Jewish practice. They followed the customs and traditions of the Ashkenazi Jewish community, which emphasized the importance of study, prayer, and observance of Jewish law. Traditional Jews in Sokolów Malopolski placed less emphasis on the role of a charismatic leader and more on the importance of individual piety and devotion.

Despite these differences, the Jewish community in Sokolów Malopolski remained cohesive and united, and there were frequent interactions and exchanges between Hasidic and traditional Jews. Both groups were committed to preserving and transmitting Jewish knowledge and tradition, and they shared a strong sense of community and solidarity.
